questions.question: You are called to see a cyanotic neonate in the NICU. You note that the neonate has anoxygen saturation of 60%. Which of the following would not be in your differential diagnosis

options.B: Ventricular septal defect with pulmonic stenosis

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common cyanotic congenital heart disease?
questions.explanation: 488The most common cyanotic congenital heart disease is tetralogy of Fallot (ToF).Infants are often asymptomatic until later in life (beyond 1yr of life).TOF has 4 components:•Obstruction to right ventricular outflow (pulmonary stenosis)• Malalignment type of ventricular septal defect (VSD)⚫ Dextroposition of the aorta so that it overrides the ventricular septum (overriding of the aorta),and• Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH)

questions.question: Below is an X-ray of an infant with cyanotic heart diease. Which is not a finding seen here?479DAILYROUNDS
questions.explanation: Cyanosis and boot-shaped heart (coeur en sabot in French) points towards tetralogy of Fallot(TOF) and the atrial septal defect is not a finding seen in TOF.Clinical findings in TOF:••Right ventricular hypertrophy causing left anterior hemithorax bulge.Single S2 or soft P2 because of the stenotic pulmonary valve•Systolic thrill in the left sternal border in 3rd and 4th parasternal spaces.• The large 'a' wave in the jugular pulse is a reflection of the forceful contraction of the right.atrium at the end of diastole as there is reduced distensibility of the hypertrophic right ventricle.There is a loud and harsh systolic murmur due to the right ventricular outflow tract (RVOT)obstruction. It becomes louder, longer, and harsher as obstruction increases in severity from mildto moderate.• However in severe obstruction, especially during tet spell, the murmur becomes less prominentas the blood is shunted towards the aortic valve and not through RVOT.Aorta(to body)Right atriumDeoxygenatedblood flow inright heartObstructionto right ventricularoutflow-PulmonicstenosisRight ventricularhypertrophyTetralogy of FallotNormal heartPulmonaryartery(to lungs)Oxygenatedblood flow inleft heartRight and left ventriclesB Heart with tetralogy of FallotCOMARROW489Dextroposition/overriding of aortaVentricularseptal defectX-Ray in TOF showing boot shaped heart:Tetralogy of Fallot-boot-shaped heartAcyanotic/pink tetralogy of Fallot: This occurs when obstruction to the right ventricular outflow ismild to moderate. The blood would flow more through the mildly obstructed RVOT and lessthrough the VSD. Hence, there is less cyanosis.

questions.question: A mother brings her 2-month-old blue baby to your pediatric clinic for the first time.Neonatal records were not available but the mother says that the X-ray of the baby looked likethat of a shoe. Which of the following wouldn't you expect in this baby?

options.D: Large "a" waves in jugular venous pulse

questions.explanation: The given history of the shoe (boot) shaped heart in cyanotic baby is suggestive of tetralogy ofFallot and cardiomegaly is not a part of TOF presentation.In the tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), we see concentric right ventricular hypertrophy without cardiacenlargement. It is because of pulmonary stenosis (PS) and the ventricular septal defect (VSD). Anybuild-up of pressure in the right ventricle due to PS is released through VSD to the left ventricle.Option A: P2 is of low intensity and soft because the right ventricular outflow obstruction results.in reduced pulmonary artery pressure.Option B: The aortic root usually appears large because it overrides (straddling) the VSD, allowingdeoxygenated blood shunted from the right ventricle mixed with blood from the left ventricle toexit the heart.Option D: The large 'a' wave in the jugular pulse is a reflection of the forceful contraction of theright atrium at the end of diastole as there is reduced distensibility of the hypertrophic rightventricle.

questions.question: A primary school teacher notices a peculiar behavior in one of her pupils. Whenever he playswith his friends, she notices that her fingers and lips turn blue. The child then squats forsometime after which he feels better. Which of the following does not occur during squatting?

options.A: It increases the systemic vascular resistance
options.B: It increases the magnitude of right-to-left shunt
options.C: Leads to trapping of deoxygenated blood in lower limbs

questions.explanation: Squatting decreases the magnitude of the right-to-left shunt in a child with tetralogy of Fallot(TOF) .490The child feels comfortable while squatting due to two compensatory mechanisms:• Increasing systemic vascular resistance and, thus, decreasing the magnitude of the right-to-leftshunt across the ventricular septal defect (VSD). Therefore, more blood goes to the lungs foroxygenation.•Trapping deoxygenated venous blood in the lower limbs.

questions.question: While waiting for corrective open-heart surgery, you decide to manage a case of tet spellsmedically. Which of the following drugs would worsen the cyanosis?
questions.explanation: Isoprenaline/isoproterenol should be avoided in tet or hypercyanotic spells. It will causea decrease in total peripheral resistance (TPR) or systemic vascular resistance (SVR). So, moreblood leaves the left ventricle leading to the increased right to left shunt. This results in theworsening of right ventricular outflow and causes worsening of cyanosis and the symptoms.Treatment of hypercyanotic spell involves placing child in knee-chest position (or squatting), anduse of:• oxygen•morphine - sedates the patient•⚫ sodium bicarbonate - to counteract metabolic acidosis that develops when arterial Po2 <40mmHg• alpha-agonists (phenylephrine)- vasopressor used in severe cases⚫ beta-blockers (propranolol)- improves resting saturation and decreases the frequency of spells.Drugs that increase SVR, such as IV phenylephrine (alpha-1 agonist) or propranolol (non-selectivebeta-antagonist/beta-2 block), can improve right ventricular outflow, decrease the right-to-leftshunt, and improve the symptoms. This is same principle as squatting.

questions.question: Blalock-Taussig shunt is done between
questions.explanation: Blalock-Taussig shunt is done between subclavian artery to pulmonary arteryBlalock-Taussig shunt is currently the most common aortopulmonary shunt procedure andconsists of a Gore-Tex conduit.Sometimes, the shunt is brought directly from the ascending aorta to the main pulmonary artery;in this case, it is called the central shunt.Corrective open-heart surgery performed in critically ill newborns and early infancy is thepreferred surgical treatment now.Name of the surgeryBlalock-Taussig shunt (BS)Waterston's shunt (WA)ConnectsSubclavian artery to pulmonary arteryAscending aorta to right pulmonary artery491Name of the surgeryConnectsPott's shunt (PD)Descending aorta to pulmonary artery

questions.question: Which of the following is a component of the pentalogy of Fallot?
questions.explanation: Pentalogy of Fallot consists of• Tetralogy of Fallot: Ventricular septal defect + Pulmonic stenosis + Overriding of the aorta +Right ventricular hypertrophy• Atrial septal defect

questions.question: An adolescent who is a known case of VSD is brought by his parents with complaints ofbreathlessness on exertion which is gradually progressive, bluish discoloration, and swellingof toes and fingers. Investigations showed features suggestive of pulmonary hypertension.Which of the following is not a part of the condition?
questions.explanation: Given clinical scenario along with the development of pulmonary hypertension is seen inEisenmenger's syndrome and predominant right to left shunt (not left to right shunt) is seen here.Gradual onset of cyanosis, dyspnoea, fatigue, and in later stages, heart failure, chest pain,headaches, syncope, and hemoptysis in a setting of congenital acyanotic heart disease, are signsand symptoms of Eisenmenger's syndrome.Reversal of the shunt at the level of atria/ventricles/patent ductus arteriosus due to irreversiblepulmonary vascular obstructive changes is defined as Eisenmenger's syndrome.Eisenmenger's syndrome pathophysiologyLeft-to-right shunt through VSD/ASD/PDAIncreased blood flow through pulmonary arteriesIncreased pulmonary vascular resistanceObstructive pulmonary hypertensionM°MIncreased pressure in the right side of the heart↓Right ventricular hypertrophyReversal of shunt - Right-to-left, or Bidirectional shuntCyanosis and clubbingOMARROWFeatures of pulmonary hypertension in Eisenmenger physiology: Right ventricular heave, narrowsplit S 2 with a loud pulmonic component.Chest X-ray showing prominent pulmonary artery and right ventricle, peripheral pruning ofpulmonary vessels.492ECG shows features of right ventricular hypertrophy, with spiked P waves.Treatment: Calcium channel blockers, prostacyclin, and it's analog treprostinil and lungtransplantation.

questions.question: The most common type of total anomalous pulmonary venous connection is
questions.explanation: The most common type of total anomalous pulmonary venous connection (TAPVC) issupracardiac.In TAPVC, pulmonary veins instead of draining into the left atrium drain into the right atriumdirectly or indirectly.•Supracardiac (most common): Common pulmonary vein drains into superior venacava or leftinnominate vein.••Cardiac: Pulmonary veins drain into right atrium or coronary sinus.• Infracardiac (always obstructive and most dangerous): Pulmonary veins drain into the hepaticvein or portal vein or inferior vena cava.

questions.question: A neonate was noted to have cyanosis of the oral mucosa. Chest x-ray revealed a snowmanappearance of the cardiac silhouette. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Snowman's appearance on the chest X-ray image is classically seen in total anomalous pulmonaryvenous connection (TAPVC).The supracardiac variant can classically depict a snowman appearance/figure of 8/cottage loafheart on the frontal chest radiograph.The dilated vertical vein on the left, brachiocephalic vein on the top, and the superior vena cavaon the right form the head of the snowman; the body of the snowman is formed by the enlargedright atrium.The image given above shows a snowman or figure-8 configuration. Cardiomegaly and increasedpulmonary vascularity are evident.493

questions.question: You are examining a week-old male infant who was severely cyanotic at birth in thepost-operative ward. He has undergone balloon atrial septostomy following prostaglandin E1administration. Post-surgery there was a marked improvement in cyanosis. The most likelydiagnosis is
questions.explanation: Cyanosis at birth, prostagladin E1 administration, and septostomy to improve oxygenation aretypical features of transposition of great vessels (TGA).TGA is characterized by the aorta arising from the right ventricle and pulmonary artery from theleft ventricle. Since systemic and pulmonary circulations are separate, survival depends on themixing of oxygenated pulmonary blood and deoxygenated systemic blood which can occur:• At atrial level: Through atrial septal defect (ASD)•At ventricle level: Through ventricular septal defect (VSD)• At great vessel level: Through patent ductus arteriosusChest X-ray image shows cardiomegaly, a narrow mediastinum (the classic "egg-on-stringappearance"), and normal to increased pulmonary blood flow. The narrow pedicle of the heart isbecause of the malposition of the great vessels.Treatment: Here, prostaglandin E1 administration and septostomy help initial stabilization bycreating a communication between the right and left atria, thereby facilitating the mixing ofsystemic and pulmonary circulations.494To lungsAorta arisingfrom the leftventricleTo lungsAorta arisingfrom the rightventricleAtrial septaldefectTransposition of great vesselsTo bodyRARVNormalTo bodyTo lungsPulmonary arteryarising from theright ventriclePatent ductusarteriosusTo lungsPulmonary arteryarising from theloftventricleTransposition of great vesselsRA - Right atriumLA - Loft atriumwRV Right ventricleLV - Loft ventricleMARROW

questions.question: A 24-year-old woman with bipolar disorder on lithium therapy expresses intent to conceive.She must be advised to stop the drug due to the risk of development of which of the followingconditions in the fetus?
questions.explanation: She must be asked to stop the intake of lithium as it can cause an Ebstein anomaly in thenewborn.Ebstein anomaly is characterized by the downward displacement of the tricuspid valve into theright ventricle, which results in a thin-walled, low-pressure, "atrialized" segment of the rightventricle due to the anomalous attachment of the tricuspid leaflets.Lithium can also cause macrocephaly as a teratogenic effect.

questions.question: 482Akshay, a high schooler presents to you with swelling of fingers and toes. He said he getspalpitations while he is exercising and even when he hangs out with friends. An X-Ray of thepatient is given below. ECG showed the presence of delta waves. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The diagnosis is Ebstein's anomaly.The presence of clubbing and a box-shaped heart on chest X-Ray in the given case is suggestive ofEbstein's anomaly. Clubbing develops secondary to cyanosis as ebstein's anomaly is a right to leftshunt. Delta wave is observed in Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome. WPW andsupraventricular tachycardia causing palpitations can be seen in association with Ebstein'sanomaly.495Ebstein's Anomaly - box-shaped heart

questions.question: In a 13-year-old child with Ebstein's anomaly, echocardiography would likely reveal:
questions.explanation: Tricuspid regurgitation would be seen in a child with an Ebstein anomaly.Mild cases develop cyanosis during adolescence or early adulthood. In severe cases, cyanosismanifests at birth.Ebstein anomaly is characterized by the downward displacement of the tricuspid valve into theright ventricle, which results in a thin-walled, low-pressure, "atrialized" segment of the rightventricle due to the anomalous attachment of the tricuspid leaflets.In Ebstein's, tricuspid valve tissue is dysplastic and results in tricuspid regurgitation.The right ventricle is hypoplastic, which leads to decreased pulmonary outflow and there will befunctional pulmonary atresia. As a result, blood shunts through the foramen ovale/atrial septaldefect (ASD) results in cyanosis at birth.Himalayan P wave (amplitude > 5 mm) is associated with tricuspid atresia, Ebsteinanomaly, and combined tricuspid and pulmonary stenosis, where they indicate a dilated rightatrium. Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome (WPW) and supraventricular tachycardia may bepresent in Ebstein anomaly.Note:In Ebstein anomaly, the malformed tricuspid valve is usually regurgitant, but may rarely bestenotic.

questions.question: A cyanotic newborn is suspected of having congenital heart disease. He has an increased leftventricular impulse and a holosystolic murmur along the left sternal border. ECG shows leftaxis deviation and left ventricular hypertrophy. Which of the following is the most likelydiagnosis?483
questions.explanation: Clinical cyanosis in combination with left-axis deviation (LAD) and left ventricular hypertrophy(LVH) noted on the electrocardiogram distinguishes tricuspid atresia from most other cyanoticheart lesions.496Other points in favor:• Increased left ventricular impulse (in contrast to most other causes of cyanotic heart disease, inwhich an increased right ventricular impulse).•⚫ Holosystolic murmurs audible along the left sternal border (due to associated ventricular septaldefect).Tricuspid atresia is the congenital absence of the tricuspid valve. So, blood cannot flow directlyfrom the right atrium to the right ventricle, and the following associated defects are necessary forsurvival:• Patent foramen ovale or atrial septal defect: for the flow of blood from the right atrium to the leftatrium• Ventricular septal defect: for the flow of blood from the left ventricle to the right ventricle••There is a hypoplastic right ventricle.Option B and D: Truncus arteriosus and tetralogy of Fallot and - The ECG demonstrates right axisdeviation (RAD) and evidence of RVH.Option A: Transposition of great arteries- ECG is usually normal, showing the neonatal right-sideddominant pattern.

questions.question: You are examining a case of cyanosis in NICU as a resident. Which of the following cardiacfeatures would make the diagnosis of tricuspid atresia unlikely?
questions.explanation: Left ventricular hypoplasia would make the diagnosis unlikely as right ventricular hypoplasia isseen in tricuspid atresia.Other features of tricuspid atresia:•• An increased left ventricular impulse is noted in contrast to an increased right ventricularimpulse seen in most other cyanotic diseases.• A VSD holosystolic murmur is audible along the left sternal border.• The second heart sound (S2) is usually single.• Left ventricular hypertrophy and left axis deviation on ECG.•• Tall, peaked P waves on lead II known as Himalayan P waves which are suggestive of anenlarged right atrium.497AortaPulmonaryarteryMPatent ductusarteriosusAortaPulmonary arteryAtrial septaldefectTricuspid atresiaRANormal heartRA3Atretictricuspid valveHypoplasticright ventricleVentricularseptal defectRVRVHeart with tricuspid atresiaRA-Right atriumLA-Left atriumLV-Left ventricleRV-Right ventricleMARROWLVTV-Tricuspid valveMV-Mitral valveAOV-Aortic valvePV-Pulmonary valve

questions.question: Which of the following cases could develop recurrent infections due to pulmonarycongestion?
questions.explanation: Patients with atrial and ventricular septal defects have increased pulmonary blood flow. Thisresults in recurrent pulmonary infection due to congestion in the lungs.Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) and tricuspid atresia (TA) are associated with reduced pulmonary bloodflow (oligemic lung fields). They do not cause pulmonary congestion and do not predispose toinfections.•Reduced pulmonary blood flow is due toRight ventricular outflow obstruction in tetralogy of Fallot•Right ventricular inflow obstruction in tricuspid atresiaCyanotic congenital heart diseases (CCHD) with decreased and increased pulmonary blood flow:Decreased pulmonary blood flowTetrology of Fallot PulmonaryatresiaEbstein's anomalyTricuspid atresia with an intact ventricular septumTransposition of the great vessels with VSD and pulmonary stenosisIncreased pulmonary blood flOWTransposition of the great vessels with VSD or PDATotal anomalous pulmonary venousreturn (TAPVC)Truncus arteriosus Hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS)

questions.question: A cyanotic baby at the 8th hour of life is being evaluated in NICU. Pulse oximetry shows 80 %not improving with 100 % 02. Records show that continuous machinery murmur was heardat birth but not anymore. Which of the following can be done?
questions.explanation: This baby has a cyanotic congenital heart disease that is dependent on a patent ductus arteriosus.Prostaglandin E1 infusion prevents the closure of PDA in term neonates with duct-dependent498congenital heart disease (CHD).Cyanosis failing to improve with 100% oxygen suggests an underlying cyanotic CHD.Duct-dependent CHD with open PDADuctus arteriosus(Open)Pulmonary stenosis(or atresia)Open PDA maintainsblood flow to the lungs.Oxygenation continuesEnsures survivalDuct-dependent CHD with closed PDAOMARROWPulmonary circulationis compromisedDuctus arteriosus(Closed)Pulmonary stenosis(or atresia)Closed PDA cannotpump blood to the lungsNo oxygenationCyanosis & hypoxiaDeathFunctional closure of the PDA occurs soon after birth, usually within first week of life.The open PDA acted as a conduit between systemic and pulmonary circulations, therebypreventing the onset of cyanosis.Upon its closure, cyanosis manifested in the baby as the blood could not be pumped into the lungsfor oxygenation. Deoxygenated blood is being shunted into the systemic circulation after theclosure of PDA. Hence, you should maintain the patency of the duct with PGE1 infusion untilsurgery can be done.Duct-dependent lesions: Anomalies, in a newborn with CHD, which are dependent on the patencyof ductus arteriosus for survival.•Right-sided lesions (Tetralogy of Fallot, PA/PS) cannot pump blood to the lungs. These patientsare dependent on an open PDA for pulmonary circulation.•Left-sided lesions (Hypoplastic left heart syndrome, Aortic stenosis, Coarctation of aorta) cannotpump blood into the systemic circulation. These patients are dependent on open PDA for systemiccirculation.

questions.question: 484The given chest X-ray is suggestive of:R
questions.explanation: The given chest X-ray shows a boot-shaped cardiac silhouette which is suggestive of the Tetralogyof Fallot.The boot-shaped (coeur en sabot) cardiac silhouette is seen due to the right ventricularhypertrophy and upward shift of the cardiac apex. The hilar areas and lung fields appear relativelyclear due to reduced pulmonary blood flow or the small size of the pulmonary arteries, or both.In Ebsteins's anomaly (Option D) box-shaped heart is seen.499

questions.question: Which among the following options describes the chest x-ray image?R
questions.explanation: The given chest x-ray shows 'coeur-en-sabot' or boot-shaped heart, which is seen in tetralogy ofFallot (TOF).The characteristic silhouette is due to cardiac apex elevation as a result of right ventricularhypertrophy. The hilar areas and lung fields are relatively clear because of diminished pulmonaryblood flow or the small size of the pulmonary arteries and the aorta is usually enlarged.The image below describes the likeness of the cardiac silhouette to a boot:Tetralogy of Fallot-boot-shaped heartRTOF is cyanotic congenital heart disease with the following four components:• Obstruction to right ventricular outflow (pulmonary stenosis)• Malalignment type of ventricular septal defect (VSD)•• Dextroposition of the aorta so that it overrides the ventricular septum (overriding of the aorta)Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH)The severity of symptoms depends on the degree of the right ventricular outflow obstruction. Inmild degrees, the symptoms become pronounced as the baby grows due to RV infundibularhypertrophy and may present with heart failure. In severe degrees, pulmonary blood flowpredominantly depends on the ductus arteriosus. As soon as the duct closes, the baby presentswith cyanosis and circulatory collapse in the neonatal period.Clinical features include significant hypercyanotic spells in infants which are characterised byhyperpnea, cyanosis, and gasping followed by syncope. The spells occur most frequently in themorning on initially awakening or after episodes of vigorous crying. These spells are due to aprolonged reduction of pulmonary blood flow resulting in severe systemic hypoxia and metabolicacidosis.Older children present with exertional dyspnea and assume a squatting position to relieve thedyspneic episode after which the child is able to resume the activity.500

questions.question: Of the following, all are findings of the condition in the below chest x-ray except:
questions.explanation: The given chest x-ray shows an egg-on-string appearance seen in the transposition of greatarteries (TGA). Enlargement of the left atrium is seen in TGA, not the right atrium.The reason for left atrial enlargement is due to increased pulmonary blood flow.TGA is characterized by the aorta arising from the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery fromthe left ventricle. This abnormal configuration leads to a narrow vascular pedicle.As pulmonary vascular resistance drops during the first few days of life, blood flow through thepulmonary vasculature is increased. There is also elevated pulmonary venous pressure seen inTGA, especially in infants with an intact interventricular septum.The globular (egg) appearance of the heart due to abnormal convexity of the right atrial borderand left atrial enlargement, and the narrow superior mediastinum (string) result in the classicalegg-on-string appearance.TGA is the most specific heart disease in infants of diabetic mothers.Early management includes an immediate infusion of prostaglandin E1 which keeps the ductusarteriosus patent for improving oxygenation. Rashkind balloon atrial septostomy is a palliativecatheter-based intervention that can be done to improve the hypoxic state before definitivesurgery. The procedure creates an opening in the atrial septum which allows betterinter-circulatory mixing of the blood. Jatene arterial switch procedure is the definitive surgery.Most infants with TGA do not survive till adulthood without corrective surgery.

questions.question: Below is the chest X-ray image obtained for a neonate on day 7 of life who developed heartfailure later. What is the most probable diagnosis?486
questions.explanation: The classic "egg on end" appearance on this chest X-ray image is seen in the transposition ofgreat arteries (TGA).In the chest X-ray image, cardiomegaly with narrow mediastinum gives rise to the classic“egg-shaped heart." The superior mediastinum appears narrow due to the anteroposteriorrelationship of the transposed great vessels and the radiologic absence of the thymus.501
